sn35.105:4.1: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn35.105:5.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn35.105:6.1: “Mendicants, when there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye, pleasure and pain arise in oneself. …
sn35.105:6.2: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
sn35.105:6.3: What do you think, mendicants? Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.105:8.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.105:10.1: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn35.105:20.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.105:22.1: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn35.105:24.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with the eye,
sn35.105:24.2: ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn35.105:24.5: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn35.105:24.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
